title: Russia's inflation fight is working — at the cost of growth
description: In July, Russia's manufacturing sector posted its steepest contraction in three years.
content: Russia may be getting its spiraling inflation under control, but it comes at a growing economic cost, according to a think tank."Current inflationary pressures, including underlying ones, are declining faster than previously forecast," Russia's central bank said last month.Russia's inflation fell from 8.2% in the first quarter to 4.8% in the second quarter, prompting its central bank to lower its key interest rate from 20% to 18%."The economy continues to return to a balanced growth path," the central bank added.That phrase is just "a euphemism for anemic growth," wrote Alexander Kolyandr, a senior fellow at the Center for European Policy Analysis, on Thursday.The Bank of Russia expects Russia's economy to grow 1% to 2% this year. Meanwhile, the International Monetary Fund expects growth of 0.9%.Russia's central bank projects the key interest rate to average between 18.8% and 19.6% this year and fall to 12% to 13% next year — a shift from aggressive interest-rate hikes from mid-2023 to tame an overheating war-fueled economy.Such high rates were effective at cooling prices. But they have also made borrowing more expensive and dampened both consumer demand and business investment.Since its full-scale invasion of Ukraine triggered sweeping Western sanctions, Russia has kept its economy afloat through massive defense spending and revenue from oil and gas exports. But that momentum may be running out.The country's GDP grew just 1.4% in the first quarter — a sharp slowdown from the previous quarter.In July, Russia's manufacturing sector posted its steepest contraction in three years, according to S&P Global's Purchasing Managers' Index."Weak client demand and financial difficulties at customers" weighed on output and new orders, wrote S&P Global. Business confidence was the lowest in three years.The slowdown in manufacturing suggests Russia's wartime economy may be losing momentum, adding pressure on policymakers to strike a delicate balance."For the Kremlin, a brief period of low growth is tolerable, though combined with lower oil prices, it would reduce fiscal revenues," CEPA's Kolyandr wrote."The main gamble is that the cooling of the economy won't trigger a prolonged recession," he added.Russia's central bank now finds itself walking a tightrope: keeping inflation in check while avoiding a deeper downturn. Continued wartime spending could easily reignite inflation, but pulling back could deepen the slowdown, especially as foreign investment remains scarce and consumer confidence weak.Meanwhile, President Donald Trump is putting pressure on Russia to end its war with Ukraine with new penalties, including secondary tariffs.Last week, Trump announced a 25% tariff on India and a "penalty" for its purchases of Russian oil.
summary: Russia's inflation control is working, but it comes at a cost of economic growth, according to a think tank, the Center for European Policy Analysis. The think tank noted that current inflationary pressures are declining faster than previously forecast, with inflation falling from 8.2% in the first quarter to 4.8% in Q2, leading the central bank to lower its key interest rate from 20% to 18%. This move comes at an economic cost as Russia's economy struggles to maintain its steady growth. The Bank of Russia expects Russia's GDP to grow by 1.4% in first quarter, a significant slowdown from the previous quarter, and the International Monetary Fund expects growth of 0.9%. The central bank also plans to average between 18.8%, and 19.6% this year and fall to 12% to 13% next year, a shift from aggressive interest-rate hikes from mid-2023 to tame an overheating war-fueled economy. Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine triggered sweeping Western sanctions, the country's economy has seen significant growth, with its manufacturing sector posting its steepest contraction in three years. Meanwhile, President Donald Trump is putting pressure on Russia to end its war with Ukraine with new penalties, including secondary tariffs.
shortSummary: Russia's inflation control measures are effective but risks diminishing economic growth, amid slowing manufacturing and rising oil prices amid US sanctions.
argos_summary: Russia's inflation has decreased from 8.2% to 4.8%, prompting the central bank to lower interest rates, but this comes at the cost of anemic economic growth, projected at only 1% to 2% for the year. The manufacturing sector is experiencing its steepest contraction in three years, indicating a potential loss of momentum in the wartime economy. Policymakers face the challenge of controlling inflation without triggering a prolonged recession, especially as Western sanctions and reduced foreign investment weigh heavily on the economy.
